questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker is having dyspnea, pitting pedal edema with hepatomegaly. On auscultation bilateral crepitations are heard with a systolic murmur heard on Left side 5th intercostal space medial to mid clavicular line. Which part of the heart is affected. SpO2 was 88% and BP normal?
questions.solution: The question deals with a valvular heart disease affecting the left side of heart, probable MR. A is the left atrium and B is the left ventricle.

questions.text:
What is correct about management of Atrial fibrillation?
1) N.O.A.C should be given in moderate to severe mitral stenosis
2) N.O.A.C are contraindicated in patients with mechanical heart valve
3) In patients of Atrial fibrillation with AIS anticoagulants like VKA, LMWH should be given within 48 hours
4) Beta blocker should be given prophylactically in patients who have undergone cardiac surgery
questions.solution: This is a factual question. All except 1 are true. NOAC are not indicated in valvular heart disease or in mechanical heart valves. In patients with AF and stroke, anticoagulation should be started.

questions.text: A case of progressive weakness of right left leg for 1 year and weakness of upper limb for the last 6 months. On examination spasticity and brisk reflexes are noted in the left leg and wasting and weakness in muscles of the upper limb. Bladder and bowel control is maintained. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Here the patient is having features of both UMN and LMN weakness with sparing of bowel and bladder and without sensory symptoms. Cervical myelopathy causes sensory symptoms. Tropical spastic paraparesis causes UMN type weakness and motor neuropathy with conduction block causes LMN weakness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old HIV positive female taking ART complains of pulsatile headache. She is prescribed ergotamine. She now develops tingling and pain in toe radiating upwards till mid thigh. Dorsalis pedis and popliteal artery pulsations are not felt bilaterally. What is etiology?
questions.solution: Ergotamine derivatives are substrates of CYP3A4 metabolism and as such are contraindicated for concomitant use with medications established as strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (protease inhibitors, some macrolide antibiotics, azole antifungals) because of the production of acute ergot toxicity. Ergotamine derivatives are substrates of CYP3A4 metabolism and as such are contraindicated for concomitant use with medications established as strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (protease inhibitors, some macrolide antibiotics, azole antifungals) because of the production of acute ergot toxicity.

Comment on core criteria seen in case of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Syndrome?
A) Focal Seizures
B) Bilateral Optic Neuritis
C) Area Postrema syndrome
D) Diencephalic Syndrome
Which of the above are correct?

choices.text: Structural heart disease and check family members for atherosclerosis
Screening in close relatives for risk of arrhythmias

questions.text: An athlete fell while running and died suddenly. The cut-section of a heart is shown. What of the following is correct about the condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question has HCM. They are at high risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. 80% have mutations in the MYH7 or MYBPC3 gene.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by age-dependent and incomplete penetrance. Ventricular hypertrophy is rarely present at birth and usually develops later in life. Women appear to have lower penetrance of sarcomere mutations and an older age at hypertrophic cardiomyopathy diagnosis but increased rates of heart failure and mortality.

Screening of family members should begin in adolescence and extend through adulthood.

In MYBPC3 mutation carriers, the average age of disease development is ~40 years, while 30% remain free from hypertrophy after 70 years.

Related individuals who carry the same mutation may have a different extent and pattern of hypertrophy (e.g., asymmetric vs concentric), occurrence of outflow tract obstruction, and associated clinical outcomes, although sudden death and progression to heart failure occur more commonly in families with that history.

choices.text: MRI head to check for ischemia
CT Angiography to look for occlusion in vessel

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset aphasia and hemiparesis. The Deficit resolved within 2 hours and the CT Scan of the patient is normal. On examination BP is 160 /110 mm Hg. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: The patient in the question has a TIA(Transient Ischemic Attack). The next best step is to find out the source of the thrombus and treat it to prevent the recurrence and stroke. CT angiography of vessels in the head and neck to find the source of the clot.

questions.text:
A case of Acid-base imbalance can be confirmed by?
A) pH arterial blood
B) pH venous blood
C) O2 venous blood
D) CO2 venous blood
questions.solution:
Acid-base imbalance can be confirmed by pH arterial blood, pH venous blood, CO2 venous blood.

Alternatives to ABG include VBG, end tidal carbon dioxide, transcutaneous carbon dioxide.

choices.text: ATT first then ART after 2 weeks
ART first then ATT after 2 weeks

questions.text: Correct about treatment of newly diagnosed tuberculosis and HIV patients when CD count is greater than 50 cells/μL?
questions.solution: Initiation of ART and/or anti-TB therapy may be associated with clinical deterioration due to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) reactions. These are most common in patients initiating both treatments at the same time, may occur as early as 1 week after initiation of ART therapy, and are seen more frequently in patients with advanced HIV disease. For these reasons it is recommended that initiation of ART be delayed in antiretroviral-naive patients with CD4 counts >50 cells/μL until 2-4 weeks following the initiation of treatment for TB. For patients with lower CD4 counts the benefits of more immediate ART outweigh the risks of IRIS, and ART should be started as soon as possible in those patients.

questions.text: Arrange in sequence for manifestations of iron toxicity
questions.solution:
The clinical course of iron toxicity is divided into five stages. The progression from stage to stage may be very rapid, and not every patient goes through every stage.

  1. During the first stage (0.5 to 6 hours), the patient mainly exhibits gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms including abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, hematemesis, and hematochezia.
  2. The second stage (6 to 24 hours) represents an apparent recovery phase, as the patient's GI symptoms may resolve despite toxic amounts of iron absorption.
  3. The third stage (6 to 72 hours) is characterized by the recurrence of GI symptoms, shock, and metabolic acidosis. Iron-induced coagulopathy, hepatic dysfunction, cardiomyopathy, and renal failure are also observed in this stage.
  4. The fourth stage (12 to 96 hours) is characterized by an elevation of aminotransferase levels and possible progression to hepatic failure.
  5. The fifth stage (2 to 8 weeks) represents the consequences of the healing of the injured GI mucosa including pyloric or proximal bowel scarring and obstruction.

A patient may present in or skip any of the five stages. Determination of the iron toxicity stage should be based on symptoms and clinical manifestations and not on time of ingestion.

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is used in treatment of ?
questions.solution: Nitric oxide is a gaseous agent that produces pulmonary vasodilation by cGMP.

choices.text: Hand foot and mouth disease with meningitis

questions.text: A child has fever with rash as shown in the pic. On examination nuchal rigidity is noted. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Vesicular lesions in mouth and palms and soles are seen in hand foot and mouth disease caused by enterovirus. They cause meningitis, myocarditis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

questions.text: Pathognomonic sign seen in Juvenile dermatomyositis is?
questions.solution:
The most common clinical manifestations at disease onset are muscle weakness, easy fatigability, skin rash, malaise, and in some cases, fever. The CK levels tend to be mildly elevated, whereas other muscle enzymes such as aspartate aminotransaminase (AST), alanine aminotransaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) might be more commonly elevated.

The skin rash is often pathognomonic and similar to that in adult DM: the most typical skin manifestations are heliotrope discoloration of the upper eyelids, Gottron's papules, periungual erythema, and capillary loop abnormalities (dilated and tortuous with decreased capillary density). Calcinosis, cutaneous ulceration, and lipodystrophy are more common in juvenile cases than in adults.

questions.text:
In a case of meningitis, CSF sugar is 40 mg%, how will you proceed?
A. CSF sample must be taken before Antibiotics
B. Blood culture before start of Antibiotics
C. ATT initiated before CSF PCR for TB
D. 1 mL CSF centrifuged will have microbiological yield of > 95%CI
questions.solution:
CSF sugar < 40 indicates bacterial meningitis or chronic meningitis due to TB or fungus.

If LP is delayed in pyogenic, empirical antibiotic therapy should be initiated after blood cultures are obtained. Antibiotic therapy initiated a few hours prior to LP will not significantly alter the CSF WBC count or glucose concentration, nor is it likely to prevent visualization of organisms by Gram's stain or detection of bacterial nucleic acid by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay. CSF sterilization may occur more rapidly after initiation of parenteral antimicrobial therapy than previously suggested, with complete sterilization of CSF containing meningococci within 2 hours, and the beginning of sterilization of pneumococci by 4 hours into therapy.

Delay in treatment of tuberculous meningitis is associated with permanent neurological damage and death, hence treatment should be started without waiting for results, if clinically indicated. Centrifuged sample has more yield.

Vitamin B6 dependency syndromes that require pharmacologic doses of vitamin B6 are cystathionine β-synthase deficiency, pyridoxine-responsive (primarily sideroblastic) anemias, and gyrate atrophy with chorioretinal degeneration due to decreased activity of the mitochondrial enzyme ornithine aminotransferase. In these situations, 100-200 mg/d of oral vitamin B6 is required for treatment.

questions.text: Which is the Gold Standard Investigation for confirming the diagnosis of myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis.

Patients with recent or ongoing viral syndromes have been classified into three levels of myocarditis diagnosis.

  1. Possible subclinical acute myocarditis is diagnosed when a typical viral syndrome occurs without cardiac symptoms, but with elevated biomarkers of cardiac injury, ECG suggestive of acute injury, and/or reduced left ventricular ejection fraction or regional wall motion abnormality.
  2. Probable acute myocarditis is diagnosed when the above criteria are met and accompanied by cardiac symptoms, such as shortness of breath or chest pain, which can result from pericarditis or myocarditis. When clinical findings of pericarditis are accompanied by elevated troponin or CK-MB or abnormal cardiac wall motion, the terms perimyocarditis or myopericarditis are sometimes used.
  3. Definite myocarditis is diagnosed when there is histologic or immunohistologic evidence of inflammation on endomyocardial biopsy and does not require any other laboratory or clinical criteria

When biopsy is performed, the key Dallas criteria for myocarditis include lymphocytic infiltrate with evidence of myocyte necrosis and are negative in 80-90% of patients with clinical myocarditis. Negative Dallas criteria can reflect sampling error or early resolution of lymphocytic infiltrates, but may also be influenced by the insensitivity of the test when inflammation results from cytokines and antibody-mediated injury.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child is admitted with hemoptysis episodes, breathlessness and cough for the past 10 days. CXR is shown below. What is the next best investigation for the patient?
questions.solution: The chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly with enlargement of left atrium and right ventricle. Most probably the patient is having a disease affecting the mitral valve which can present with hemoptysis. It can be confirmed using a 2D echo.
